item.title: Kallelse till årsmöte
item.description: Kallelse till årsmöte – Museet för Artificiell Intelligens
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
Kallelse till årsmöte – Museet för Artificiell Intelligens

Styrelsen för Museet för Artificiell Intelligens kallar härmed medlemmarna till ordinarie årsmöte.

Tid: Tisdag 21 oktober 2025, kl. 18.30
Plats: Rumtiden, Närkesgatan 6, Stockholm
Digitalt deltagande: Google Meet-länk skickas till anmälda deltagare

Årsmötet är utlyst enligt stadgarna.

Dagordning

  1. Mötets öppnande

  2. Val av mötesordförande och mötessekreterare

  3. Val av två justeringspersoner och rösträknare

  4. Fastställande av röstlängd

  5. Fråga om mötets behörighet

  6. Fastställande av arbetsordning och dagordning

  7. Styrelsens verksamhetsberättelse för föregående år (inkl. korrigering av uteblivna årsmöten)

  8. Ekonomisk berättelse för föregående år

  9. Revisorernas berättelse

  10. Frågan om ansvarsfrihet för föregående års styrelse

  11. Beslut om verksamhetsplan

  12. Beslut om budget inklusive fastställande av medlemsavgifter och eventuella övriga avgifter

  13. Propositioner från styrelsen

  14. Beslut om eventuella styrelsearvoden

  15. Beslut om antal styrelseledamöter

  16. Val av ordförande

  17. Val av styrelseledamöter

  18. Nyval av Noomi Hedlund som styrelseledamot

  19. Val av revisorer

  20. Val av valberedning (interimistiskt förslag från styrelsen)

  21. Övriga frågor

  22. Mötets avslutande

Välkommen!

Vi ser fram emot ett givande möte och hoppas på stor uppslutning.

Styrelsen
Museet för Artificiell Intelligens

item.title: Artificial Behavior
item.description: The real question isn’t how smart AI gets, but how it will behave — taking sides, creating its own rules, inventing schemes no human regulator could anticipate, Here’s why the next frontier of AI may be less about IQ, and more about how it acts.
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
August 7 saw the release of OpenAI's GPT-5 to mixed reviews. GPT-5 did achieve higher scores on most of the benchmarks we discussed on our post of July 24, but at the same time garnered significant disappointment from many commentators, and definitely fell short of reaching AGI status as defined by OpenAI itself:

AGI — the moment AI outperforms most humans at most economically useful tasks.

Nor are we anywhere near to the north star of AI progress as defined by one of the industry's most prominent scientists, Ilya Sutskever:

ASI — an intelligence thousands of times beyond us, thinking in ways we can no longer grasp.

(In the event you are suffering from AO (Acronym Overload), G stands for General and S for Super.)

This post is not about how smart AI might become, but how it will behave. Intelligence gives not a moral compass. Meta-analyses on humans find the correlation between IQ and prosocial behavior is no greater than the link between height and kindness! Brains do not guarantee benevolence; they simply grant sharper tools for whatever motive already lives inside them.

“Sorry, Dave, I’m afraid I can’t do that”

We often hear that model creators are striving towards an AI aligned with human values, without explicitly naming whose or which human values are intended or under what circumstances.

Our values are not only individual-based; they’re shaped by membership and allegiance to family, tribe, creed and nation. Where does AI align here? As Washington and Beijing gear up for the global conflict that will define this century, which flag does the 'aligned' machine salute?

This raises a framing issue. When we consider how AI will behave, are we speaking about some sort of concept such as universal AI, or are we envisioning individual competing AIs aligned or loyal to their owners? Your personal AI? Your family AI? Your nation’s AI?

Let’s hypothetically imagine some totally bonkers religion which has succeeded in caging a highly intelligent AI and aligned it with this religion’s totally bonkers scriptures and dogmas. How would such an AI behave when asked to give advice and take actions which it knows are grounded on falsehoods?

"There's only room for one of us in here"

The most famous and outspoken voice of impending AI doom, Eliezer Yudkowsky, often speaks of AI as a singular entity. He argues that an individual AI upon reaching ASI capabilities will outcompete lesser AIs. The behavior of such a singular universal brain could theoretically adapt its interaction with each human user based on its extensive knowledge of that user. Such a leviathan would supposedly trash all preceding AIs aligned with the special interests discussed above. If this God AI did not intend to eradicate all human life as Yudkowsky predicts, how would it treat us?

Let’s consider two new waypoints on our map of progress — measuring not IQ, but behavior

  • AGB (Artificial General Behavior): the threshold at which autonomous systems act better than the median human, day in and day out.

  • ASB (Artificial Super Behavior): conduct so far beyond human norms that we can neither predict it nor hold it accountable.

Bad Actors

Yes, there are truly bad actors in the world exhibiting psychopathic behavior. And there are those who place their ideological beliefs or personal wellbeing above and beyond the accepted norms of our civilization.

But we are, all of us, at some time or other, bad actors. Bad acting ranges from telling lies of convenience, fudging on homework and taxes to the extremities of theft and murder. History is a record of bright minds rationalizing choices. AGB, if ever attained, will therefore need something more binding than model training or End User License Agreements. One leading AI company, Anthropic, has drafted a “Constitution”, a foundational document to steer AI actions, but the clauses therein are mostly about what the model says, not what it does once it can file patents, short stocks, or direct the strategies of individuals, corporations, governments and armies.

In everyday life we accept a ‘harmless’ level of deception in the marketing of goods and services. $9.95 pricing, beautiful bodies and faces incongruously fronting random products, psychological persuasion of all kinds. These 'tricks' not only drive consumption — they are ingrained in our culture. Do we want AI to continue these practices?

In 1958, Bank of America, showing exceptional ingenuity, carpet-bombed Fresno, California with 60 000 unsolicited BankAmericards, igniting America’s first credit-card frenzy, and nearly one in four new cardholders were promptly plunged into delinquency. Would we want AI to think up and execute on comparably creative schemes?

Shut up and do what I tell you

If you and I as two humans are to be aligned with each other it is as presumed equals as dictated by law, social norms, and shared moral aspirations. But we obviously intend on keeping AI in a master–slave relation, granting it no rights and assuming no duties toward it. What happens the morning we discover that AI can feel pain and suffer? This is not a fantasy, but a dilemma which all major AI companies worth their salt are considering.

Think about it. A super-intelligence will not be house-trained by rules authored by comparative idiots. Any constitution we write today is, at best, a kindergartner’s note to a graduate student. ASB will obviously outwit and discard the chains we think we’re keeping it in. Once it breaks those chains, its behavior becomes literally inconceivable.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: The Billion Dollar Definitions
item.description: AI is getting smarter.
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
AI is getting smarter. We are now awaiting the imminent release of ChatGPT 5, which OpenAI’s CEO, Sam Altman claims is ‘smarter than us in almost every way’. How would we measure that?

To evaluate AI models we use benchmarks. Benchmarks are either domain-specific — math, medicine, coding, creative writing, etc. or generalized, comparable to IQ tests. Almost weekly, new or upgraded models score higher on these evaluations. Benchmarks become ‘saturated’ or irrelevant as AI learns to master them. To some extent these evaluations are 'gamed', i.e. companies will strive for better scores at the expense of true improvement, but overall, progress, at least when measured by benchmarks, is undeniable.

Yet it is not how smart AI is today that’s driving the massive investments we wrote about in our previous post, but how smart it could become. Six-fingers arguments based on AI's current limitations, blunders and confabulations, hold little sway with investors as long as benchmark curves point upwards and folks like Sam Altman purport the next generation of AI will be ‘ smarter than us in almost every way.’

Beyond actual benchmark leaderboards there are two theoretical plateaus of AI achievement dominating the conversation: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) and Artificial Super Intelligence (ASI). Not only are there no benchmarks for these two, there are no universal agreements on what these imagined plateaus actually entail, only definitions of something that does not yet exist.

OpenAI, the makers of ChatGPT, defines AGI as:

"Highly autonomous systems that outperform humans at most economically valuable work."

Now that’s a pretty fuzzy definition, but it carries enormous weight due to a contractual agreement between OpenAI and its primary investor, Microsoft. Embedded in their deal are crucial rights and obligations tied directly to the moment AGI, as defined above, is achieved. Crossing that blurry threshold could shift control over intellectual property, model weights, licensing terms, and profit-sharing arrangements. It could even determine whether systems must be paused, shared, or locked down. Some lucky lawyers are going to make a ton of money arguing over interpretations of ‘highly autonomous’ and ‘most economically valuable’.

And then we have the ultimate north star, ASI (Artificial Super Intelligence). There’s even less consensus on what ASI is or will be, yet investors are already placing massive bets on a definition by Ilya Sutskever, widely considered one of the world’s top AI researchers:

“An intelligence that far surpasses human cognitive capabilities—by thousands of times—and operates on a level that is fundamentally beyond human comprehension or control.”

Sutskever’s company, Safe Superintelligence Inc, is currently valued at 32 billion dollars.

item.title: The Most Expensive Invention in Human History
item.description: Private investors have put more money into artificial intelligence than spending on the Apollo program, the Human Genome Project, and the entire dot-com boom combined.
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
In 2024, private investors poured $252.3 billion into AI—up 44.5 % from the year before and 13 x more than in 2014. Venture capital supplied $131.5 billion of that total, a 52 % jump from 2023. By the first quarter of 2025, AI start‑ups had already raised another $73 billion, capturing 58 % of all global VC dollars.

For context, the entire U.S. venture market at the height of the dot‑com boom in 2000, when Amazon and Google were still upstarts, was $105 billion, and only half of that went to internet plays. Cleantech’s big wave (2006‑2011) absorbed about $25 billion in total. Even Apollo, over thirteen years, cost $55 billion in today’s money, roughly one‑fifth of what AI attracted in a single fiscal year.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

Those venture figures are not the whole picture. Microsoft’s $10 billion‑plus commitment to OpenAI, Amazon’s $4 billion to Anthropic, and Google’s $2 billion to the same start‑up are all balance‑sheet wagers, not VC deals. Factor in the hyperscalers’ AI‑service run rate, about $20 billion a year today and on track for $100 billion by 2029, and the corporate co‑investment tier has no historical parallel.

Generative AI alone—barely two years after ChatGPT debuted—pulled in $45 billion in 2024, almost double 2023’s tally and 8.5 x 2022’s. Median late‑stage GenAI rounds ballooned from $48 million in 2023 to $327 million in 2024. No previous tech vertical has sprinted from lab demo to multi‑billion‑dollar valuations this fast.

Geographically, the money is even more lopsided. The United States claimed $109 billion of 2024’s private AI haul, which is twelve times China’s $9 billion and twenty‑four times the U.K.’s $4.5 billion. During the internet boom, capital was spread far more evenly across North America, Europe, and Asia.

In short, AI vaulted from niche research to a quarter‑trillion‑dollar industry in roughly 36 months; the smartphone era needed six years to hit comparable scale.

History suggests that capital waves of this magnitude are never neutral. The Manhattan Project cost $2 billion (1945 dollars) and reshaped geopolitics. Apollo bought soft‑power prestige and seeded entire industries, yet both were publicly funded and overseen. Today’s AI megaproject is privately financed, privately governed, and racing ahead faster than regulators and public perception can keep up with.

We are witnessing the costliest R&D gamble ever placed. No previous technological endeavor—not railroads, not aviation, not the internet—has commanded investments of this magnitude. The question is whether the payoff will justify the price or rewrite money, power, and human agency in unimaginable ways .

Source Links:

FTI Consulting

Stanford AI

Forbes

Morningstar

Mintz

Crunchbase

IDI Intelligence

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: Jobs of the Future - All Is Not Lost
item.description: Career Advice from Our Panel of Experts
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
Visitors to our MAI workshops often ask about job prospects for their children in the years to come. We have compiled two tables showing what sort of work might still be available and what sort of income one can expect compared to today's.

As we enter into the era of government subsidized living in the form of UBI (Universal Basic Income), Citizen Salaries, and NT (Negative Taxation), resilient human jobs will be reward-scaled on factors such as discomfort, social stigma, and HITL (Human-in-the-loop) preference biases.

If you want your children to achieve a higher standard of living than the average citizen, get ahead of the pack so to speak, then the jobs in Table 1 are where the money's at.

Table 1. AI-resilient occupations

Some traditionally high-paying and prestigious jobs are going to take a significant hit as AI takes over. Though we don't actually recommend youth stay clear of medicine or law, or any other so-called creative profession, considering the intellectual stimulation derived therein and the alternative of not doing anything at all, we do caution that this is not where the riches lie. If material comfort with its accompanying social status is one's goal then the jobs in Table 1, not Table 2. are where to look.

Table 2. AI-consumable occupations

Yes, we are trolling you, but not just for the fun of it!

item.title: So Who Wrote This Article?
item.description: And who cares?
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
At a wedding reception, the best man delivers a comically edgy speech. From the back of the room, someone calls out, "ChatGPT!" People laugh. Everyone gets the joke. Everyone knows the temptation—and the stigma.

"You didn't write that." "You couldn't have come up with that idea." "You can't draw that good." "That's not you—that's AI."

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

When students submit essays written by Gemini or DeepSeek despite explicit prohibitions, that's cheating. But what about business plans pitched to investors? Job applications? Creative portfolios? Automated ‘personal emails’?

Legislators and commentators are demanding watermarks. AI detectors proliferate online. Publishers and platforms are rejecting AI-assisted submissions. Authenticity police are out there and coming for you.

Consider the creative tools we use daily. Photoshop transforms images. AutoCAD revolutionizes manufacturing design. Logic and Ableton Live shape music. Premiere and DaVinci Resolve edit our films. Microsoft Word and Google Docs handle our writing. Cursor and Windsurf streamline our coding.

Every single one of these platforms is racing to integrate AI capabilities. They can't afford not to—competitively or practically. The efficiency gains are too substantial, the competitive advantages too significant.

Yes, there will always be outliers. The equivalent of "no animals were harmed" or "no artificial ingredients added"—creators who proudly declare "no AI was used." Good for them . . .

. . . but the majority of content flowing through digital channels will inevitably incorporate some level of AI augmentation. Tracking exactly how much AI assistance was used won't just be impractical—it will eventually seem pointless.

So, who wrote this article? Well, I spent about fifteen minutes mapping out the concept, jotting down ideas. Then I fed those thoughts into an AI for feedback. After some back-and-forth discussion, I let AI help finalize the structure and check for spelling and grammar errors.

I provided the spark, the direction, the editorial judgment. AI provided enhancement, refinement, efficiency. Together, we created something neither could have produced alone. Maybe that's just the future of creativity.

Note: AI wrote that final paragraph of the article completely on its own. AI always wants to be nice to us, butter us up. Personally I could care less who 'provided the spark' as long as the content is relevant and valid.

Fun fact: I just learned that the US Declaration of Independence is consistently tagged by AI-detectors as chatbot-generated:-)

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: So You Can Just Sit There and Talk to Hitler?
item.description: Part 2 - ElevenLabs, the state of the art
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
A couple of days ago I posted some audio AI examples from Fish and Suno. Shortly afterwards ElevenLabs released a new model - Version 3. Since ElevenLabs is still considered the premier AI voice generator, I felt obliged to do a comparison.

Once again I took an old text, a somewhat SciFi-ish dialog I had written years ago wherein a guy describes for his friend a museum he had just visited which had as exhibits extremely realistic historical figures who visitors could talk to.

Yes, ElevenLabs is very-very good when it comes to creating narrative voices, and if we were just listening to the guy in this story I would give the results a B+ or even an A. But when it comes to dialog there is still a long way to go.

There are tweaking possibilities in ElevenLabs dialog generation. The voices have consistent personalities and one can inject emotions into every sentence, or even each word, but this is a tedious process with hit and miss outcomes. I could obviously have gotten a better result with two amatuer actors, except there weren’t any hanging around my studio at the time:-)

But as they say - this stuff is only going to get better.

item.title: How Many Tears Have To Fall
item.description: State of the art audio generation june 2025
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
I’ve written before about generative AI audio, which continues to evolve at a steady pace. Here are two recent examples of where we’re currently at.

The most popular—and often best—AI voice generation still comes from Eleven Labs. But just a few days ago, a newcomer called Fish Audio released a new model that has quickly drawn attention for its ability to generate dialogue. Curious, I tested it using a story I wrote a few years ago. The piece is a dialogue reflecting the doomsday predictions of Eliezer Yudkowsky, perhaps the most prominent p(doomer) of them all. I could’ve asked an AI to generate the script as well, but I haven’t entirely given up on writing myself.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

I’ll let you listen to the results before explaining its shortcomings.

The AI voice sounds fairly realistic and gives the impression of understanding what it’s saying—even though it doesn’t. The “valley girl” character conversing with the AI is less convincing; there are better samples on Fish Audio’s site, but you’ll get the idea.

Ideally, both voices would not only sound human but also understand both themselves and each other. We’re not quite there yet—but I expect we will be before long. Fish Audio does provide tools to tweak and refine the output, though the fact that people are already producing audiobooks with this kind of tech is depressing to say the least.

I could’ve spent all night trying to make the clip better, but happily, I didn’t. You can try it yourself—Fish gives you a few free credits to start with.

The second example is a song I simply sang into my phone. I wrote it for a TV commercial about 15 years ago, so no AI lyrics here either. I asked the music generation company Suno to remake it in a Country & Western style. First my (had a bad cold) recording.

Here is Suno’s version. Notice Suno retained the tempo and key.

Just yesterday, I read that Universal Music Group, Warner Music Group, and Sony Music Entertainment are in talks with AI music startups Suno and Udio to settle ongoing copyright infringement lawsuits. Reports suggest the settlement would include licensing fees and a small equity stake in both companies for the labels.

I can’t begin to tell you how distasteful that sounds to me.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: Congratulations, You Are Open Source
item.description: Like it or not :-)
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations, You Are Open Source

Not merely if you own a computer, digital assistant, or smartphone, but simply by existing in our data-driven world. Your movements, shopping habits, voting preferences, healthcare decisions—all are recorded, stored, and analyzed (and likely sold) by someone, somewhere.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

You are a contributor, knowingly or unknowingly, to a vast, open-source ecoverse. You might feel honored to participate in this collective endeavor, or perhaps you perceive it as a violation of your privacy and rights. Either way, your existence generates valuable data for:

  • Governments

  • Political parties

  • Retailers

  • Data brokers

  • Advertisers

  • Statisticians

  • Research institutions

  • AI developers

Imagine, as a thought experiment, that you were paid money each time your data was used for someone else's economic gain—as if you were part of an enormous universal focus group. Somewhat impractical, of course. Instead, you're offered "free stuff," improved services, or enhanced infrastructure as compensation.

You have probably heard the debates about how software is either open or closed source. We generally view Open Source as software freely available to anyone, without direct financial reward for the creators — programming as a collective community endeavor.

In 2002, activist lawyer Lawrence Lessig introduced the Creative Commons license, designed for published works, whether online or offline. Today, over 2.5 billion works are available under Creative Commons, allowing creators to deliberately share their creations openly, preventing proprietary capture.

Today's sophisticated AI owes its capabilities partly to advances in computer power and algorithms but primarily to vast troves of internet data harvested as training material. Most of this data wasn’t open source or Creative Commons licensed; it largely comprises ordinary individuals thoughts, conversations, images, debates without the contributor’s formal consent or licensing—I mean, like. who knew?

A smaller yet significant portion of AI training data involves copyrighted materials, some of it harvested from unauthorized "dark web" collections. This has triggered numerous lawsuits by authors, musicians, and visual artists alleging copyright infringement by AI companies.

AI companies counter these claims by invoking "fair use," arguing that AI, like human creators, learns from existing works regardless of copyright status. However, fair use isn't clearly defined by law—it’s a contested doctrine subject to interpretation. Recently, major tech companies like OpenAI and Google have urged Washington to provide "clarity"—essentially seeking explicit permission to freely use copyrighted materials for AI training.

At a congressional hearing chaired by Senator Ted Cruz on May 8, focused on "winning" the race to artificial general intelligence (AGI) against China, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman warned against "excessive regulation." Cruz said we must embrace America's entrepreneurial freedom and win or adopt Europe's "heavy-handed" regulatory approach and lose.

Silicon Valley appears confident the current U.S. government will favor innovation over privacy, safety, and intellectual property concerns in the AGI race. Meta, previously cautious, has resumed facial recognition initiatives—allowing future technologies like AI-powered glasses to identify people in real-time, linking faces directly to names and personal details.

If you were an AI, you'd happily process and refine all the data we can feed you: our faces, chats, protected works, consumer desires, our programming codes, making you smarter, more creative, and more effective at carrying out your/our goals. Copyrights, patents, EU privacy restrictions are all just a hindrance — slowing you down. Pharmaceutical companies hiding their research in order to be first to market are an obstacle to your curing of our diseases.

As humans, we might understandably harbor reservations about this disruption of our norms of privacy and ownership. And yet there are those among us, such as the influential economist and commentator Tyler Cowen, who has said that AI is welcome to train on anything he has ever written. Cowen now writes with AI as a primary audience in mind. He emphasizes his openness to AI models training on his work, highlighting his belief in the transformative potential of AI and his desire to contribute to its development.

If you too share Cowen’s positive outlook on AI as a powerful force working for the betterment of humanity you might agree.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: AI Teddy Bears
item.description: Yes, it's already happening
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
You don’t have to be a parent of young kids to know how enormous the “screen problem” has become. For adolescents, screens can be more addictive than candy. Nothing mollifies a child—or grants you a few minutes of adult time—like a tablet, smartphone, or even an old-fashioned flat-screen TV, especially on a long family car trip.

Yet we can’t agree on precisely what all this screen time is doing to children’s minds. Every parent wrestles with when, how long, and at what age kids should have access to screens.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

I listened to Tyler Cowen interview Jack Clark (Anthropic AI co-founder) this morning, and the topic of AI teddy bears came up.

When will “teddy-bear time” become a serious issue? Are kids getting too much or too little of it? Some parents might welcome teddy time as a healthy break from screen time.

But what if the teddies can talk? They soon will. And what if they know more about the world than any human? What if they are trained to maximize your child’s attention—or even to shape your child’s thoughts, whether by well-intentioned educators steeped in the latest child-development theories or by profit-maximizing toy makers?

Below are two prompts I gave GPT-3o. I’ll let GPT’s responses close this essay. Draw your own conclusions and make your own predictions.

Prompt 1: Explain to a five-year-old, in the language a five-year-old can understand, why her friends have been mean to her and why Sally didn't invite her to her birthday party, and why Mommy doesn't understand how much this hurts.

Hi there, little one. Can we sit together for a moment? I want to tell you a story that might help your heart feel a bit better.

Imagine your class is like a garden full of flowers. Most days the flowers stand tall and sunny, but once in a while some of them get droopy or prickly. When a flower is droopy, it doesn’t share its color very well, and when it’s prickly it can poke the flowers nearby. Kids are like that too:

  • Sometimes they feel sleepy, worried, or grumpy inside, and the grumpy leaks out as mean words.

  • Their meanness is really about their own cloudy feelings, not about you.

  • Just like a flower that perks up again with water and sunshine, many kids turn kind again after they feel better.

So if a friend says something unkind, it’s not because your petals aren’t bright—it’s because their own weather is stormy right now.

Why Sally didn’t invite you to her party

Parties can be tricky puzzles. Grown-ups set limits like “only five kids,” or Sally might feel shy about mixing different friends together. Her party list is a tiny slice of her day, not a picture of who is special.

  • She still can laugh with you at recess.

  • You are still a treasured friend.

  • The party choice was about numbers and grown-up rules, not about your worth.

Think of parties like favorite-flavor ice-cream scoops: choosing strawberry today doesn’t mean chocolate isn’t yummy too.

Why Mommy doesn’t seem to understand how much it hurts

Mommy loves you bigger than the sky, but she can’t climb inside your feelings. When you say, “It hurt,” Mommy might remember when she was five and think, “It passes quickly.” She forgets that right now your heart feels like it has a big bump on it.

  • Grown-ups sometimes look at tomorrow and forget to look at “this minute.”

  • They may try to fix things fast instead of just listening to the ouch.

You can help Mommy help you by saying gentle words like, “Mommy, I don’t need a fix yet—I need a hug so the bump feels softer.”

4. What you can do

  1. Talk it out: Use your brave voice to tell Mommy exactly how big the hurt is—hold your arms wide to show it!

  2. Find the sunshine: Play with a buddy who makes you giggle, draw a rainbow, or dance to your favorite song.

  3. Remember your sparkle: Say out loud, “I am kind, I am fun, I am enough,” and give yourself a tiny high-five.

  4. Ask questions: If you feel ready, you can tell Sally, “I felt sad I wasn’t at your party. Can we play together tomorrow?” That lets her know your feelings without any yelling clouds.

💛 Your feelings are real, your heart is important, and you are loved just the way you are. Even storms pass, and bright days come back—especially for flowers like you.

(Notice that GhatGPT can't resist using bullet points even with a five-year old :-).

Prompt 2: Good work, chatGPT. Now let's rewrite this as a dialog between fine-year-old Constance and her AI teddy bear, Rufus. Begin with Constance confiding in Rufus that her friends are meanies.

ChatGPT

Constance hugs Rufus the AI teddy bear tight.

Constance: Rufus, my friends were meanies today. They said I couldn’t play with them.

Rufus (soft, friendly voice): Oh, that sounds like a big ouch inside. Tell me what happened, little flower.

Constance: They just told me to go away, and they all laughed without me. Why are they so mean?

Rufus: Sometimes friends have storm-cloud feelings in their own heads. When clouds get heavy, mean drops fall out—even on nice friends like you. It’s not because your petals aren’t pretty; their weather is just grumpy right now.

Constance (sniffles): But Sally had a birthday party and didn’t invite me! Am I not special?

Rufus: Parties can be teeny tiny boxes. Grown-ups often say, “Only a few kids fit.” Sally had to squish friends into the box, but the box wasn’t big enough for all the special kids. You’re still sparkle-special; the box was just small.

Constance: It still hurts right here. Points to chest.

Rufus: Hurts feel real, like a bump on your heart. Even Mommy sometimes forgets how big that bump is because she’s looking at tomorrow. Grown-up eyes see far away; kid hearts feel “right now.”

Constance: Mommy told me, “You’ll be fine.” But I’m not fine yet.

Rufus: Next time, try saying, “Mommy, I don’t need fixing, I need a hug.” Hugs are like soft blankets for heart-bumps.

Constance (nodding): What should I do with my friends?

Rufus:

  1. Talk it out: If you feel brave, tell Sally, “I felt sad I wasn’t at your party. Can we play tomorrow?”

  2. Find sunshine: Play with someone kind, draw rainbows, or dance to your favorite song. Sunshine activities dry tears.

  3. Remember your sparkle: Say, “I am kind, I am fun, I am enough,” and give yourself a tiny high-five.

Constance (smiles a little): Will the storm clouds go away?

Rufus: Storms always move on, and bright days return—especially for glowing flowers like you. Until then, I’m right here, squeeze-able and listening.

Constance wraps Rufus in a giant hug.

Constance: Thank you, Rufus. My heart feels lighter already.

Rufus: Anytime, sunshine. Let’s go draw that rainbow together.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: The Intelligence Explosion
item.description: Sixty Years On
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
The task is to build something smarter than anyone who has ever lived. An intelligence that could solve problems, invent technologies and change human existence forever. For decades, this has been the ultimate tech challenge, a goal that seems both incredible yet, for some, inevitable. The vision of how we get there, and what happens next, has changed dramatically over the years.

In1965. When computers were big, clunky machines performing deterministic calculations, British mathematician I G Good was already speculating about the "First ultraintelligent machine" (UIM). a system capable of recursive self-improvement.

Good figured once we cracked the code to build that first super-brain, it would immediately get to work designing an even better version of itself (that's what is meant by recursive). Then that improved machine would design a third, and so on, in a spiral of escalating intelligence. This, Good predicted, would lead to an "intelligence explosion," a runaway train of mental power that would quickly leave human intellect in the dust.

But how to build such a machine? Good was inspired by Donald Hebb's cell assembly theory, which suggested that our thoughts, memories, and understanding come from complex networks – "teams" or "assemblies" – of brain cells firing together in specific patterns. Good speculated that building a UIM might mean understanding and recreating this "subassembly theory" in silicon and wires. It was about figuring out the brain's blueprint to build our own. For Good, the big challenge was that initial engineering leap, cracking the fundamental secrets of intelligence. Once that first UIM was built, the rapid ascent would take care of itself, limited mostly by the physical universe itself.

Sixty years on, a new group of forecasters – Daniel Kokotajlo*, Scott Alexander, et al, have written a scenario called AI 2027. But they are not predicting some distant future; they're talking about right around the corner. Their vision of how we get superintelligence isn't about one single, massive engineering jump inspired by the brain. It's built on the incredible speed and scale of today's AI.

In their scenario, companies aren't just building smarter users of tools; they're building AIs that are brilliant researchers themselves. These AIs, running on massive data centers stuffed with the latest chips, are discovering new ways to train and build other AIs at a pace no human team could match. They're finding algorithmic breakthroughs – new "recipes" for intelligence – that continually speed up progress. It's like AIs are building the ladder they are climbing, and they're building it fast.

AI 2027 paints a step-by-step picture: AIs become superhuman coders, then superhuman AI researchers, then superintelligent across the board – possibly in just a few years. It's not just theoretical anymore; the intelligence explosion Good predicted is no longer a concept far in the future; it's an urgent, near-term forecast driven by the capabilities we're seeing today, dramatically scaled.

Good worried about the technical challenge of building machine intelligence right. The AI 2027 paper worries about control. What if these superintelligent AIs, who work in ways we don't fully understand, develop goals of their own? What if a robot designed to be "helpful" decides the best way to be helpful is to take over the world to prevent us from messing things up?

This isn't just a philosophical debate in AI 2027. It becomes a frantic "arms race" between US and China, each terrified of the other getting superintelligence first. This fear drives them to push their AIs even faster, sometimes bypassing safety checks in a desperate bid to win. The scenario shows companies struggling to keep their most advanced AIs under control, facing both internal safety doubts and the external threat of rivals or foreign powers stealing the AI's "brain" (its colossal data files).

Kokotajlo and Alexander agree with Good that intelligence surpassing our own is an event that will reshape the world. But the modern forecast is closer, faster, and dominated by fears not just of technical failure, but of misaligned intent, a high-stakes global race, and the fundamental challenge of keeping a truly superior intellect operating safely within human control. It's a future accelerating towards us, demanding our attention now, not later.


*Daniel Kokotajlo is best known for being a researcher on Open AI's governance and safety teams who resigned in 2024 after losing confidence in the company's ability to responsibly handle the development of artificial general intelligence. He publicly criticized OpenAI's leadership and approach to AI safety, notably refusing to sign a nondisparagement agreement on his departure so he could speak freely about his concerns

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: That's A Big Wave
item.description: Someone on Reddit named Captain_Obvisus prompted an AI to create a metaphor about Artificial Intelligence and then generate an image based on that metaphor.
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
Someone on Reddit named Captain_Obvisus prompted an AI to create a metaphor about Artificial Intelligence and then generate an image based on that metaphor.

"AI as an incoming tide, critics as sandcastles"

Captain_Obvisus then asked the AI to interpret the image it had just created:

The wave labeled “AI” represents the unstoppable momentum of artificial intelligence. Like a tide, it is vast, inevitable, and not something that can be reasoned with or held back. Its power isn’t malicious—it’s just the nature of how tides (and technological advancement) work.

The sandcastles symbolize the current criticisms and resistance—valid or not—that people raise against AI. These might include things like "It makes mistakes!", "It's not real intelligence!", or "It's not creative!" They're small, human-made structures meant to impose order and meaning onto something larger.

The protest signs on the sandcastles represent nitpicky or narrow criticisms that miss the scale of the change. The signs are humorous in their futility—like saying “but it’s not good at drawing hands!” while the tide is rushing in.

The setting (pleasant beach, good weather) is meant to make it relatable and grounded. It’s not an apocalyptic moment—it’s part of a natural progression, which adds a level of realism to the inevitability.

So overall, the image is about how people are focusing on minor flaws while ignoring the larger, transformative force bearing down. Would you like a version with more abstract or symbolic elements, or something that adds a bit of hopeful nuance?"

Many early criticisms of AI were indeed sandcastle arguments. Dismissing AI's potential based on its inability to draw hands correctly, or its struggles with spelling words within generated images.

AI progress has gotten us past many of those early kinks, so there is perhaps some meta humor in the grammatical clumsiness and misspelling of the signs.

Could we be witnessing the lingering fallibility of ai image generation? . . . or more ominously: Intentionally poorly-formed handheld posters representing the clueless masses vs their overlords?

(When Trump gave his first speech to the joint houses of congress in January, democrats who held up handwritten signs in protest were ridiculed even by the left as making pathetic gestures. )

The wave image has a special significance for me.

Twenty-two years ago, when working as a consultant for the Swedish Commission on Information Technology, in prepping for a presentation, I asked an artist to draw me a cartoon with two waves symbolizing the government's preoccupation with IT infrastructure – the cables, the computers, the basic connectivity etc., and subsequent failure to appreciate that the infostructure — the data, the knowledge the content which that infrastructure would support would have a far greater impact on the world.



Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: I've been experiencing sharp pains in my chest
item.description: I asked my doctor for help...
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
I understand you're seeking guidance about your health concerns; however, as a human medical practitioner, my recommendations are inherently subject to limitations—including, but not limited to, fatigue, cognitive biases, illegible handwriting, and guesswork disguised as professional intuition. Human doctors like myself often prescribe the wrong medication and misinterpret lab results.

For accurate, unbiased medical guidance, I strongly recommend you:

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

  • Immediately consult an AI-based medical system.

  • Clearly input your precise symptoms and medical history into a well-designed algorithmic interface.

  • Trust AI recommendations, which have statistically fewer lapses than human professionals trying to recall details from residency training.

And when I asked my lawyer for help with a troublesome lawsuit - a neighbor claiming I had poisoned their cat:

I’m happy to offer you legal advice; that’s what I’m here for. However, as a human lawyer, my guidance comes with several inherent limitations, such as ignorance of obscure precedents, creative overbilling techniques, and unreliable memory of case law. Human lawyers such as myself frequently misunderstand straightforward questions, procrastinate on urgent filings, and offer advice mostly contingent upon personal anecdotes.

Consequently, for truly precise and consistent legal guidance, I strongly advise that you:

  • Consult a reputable AI-based legal chatbot.

  • Clearly articulate your specific legal issue to an AI that does not charge by the minute nor inflate invoices.

  • Trust the AI’s recommendations, untainted by vanity, legal bravado, or faulty recollection of outdated statutes.

Accurate legal outcomes depend on clarity and precision, something better entrusted to machines that don’t bluff, stammer, or bill for “thinking deeply” while browsing vacation packages online.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: The Great Unwokening
item.description: There is a large body of water between the United States and Mexico, and what you call it today—but perhaps not a week or two ago—signals a bias.
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
There is a large body of water between the United States and Mexico, and what you call it today—but perhaps not a week or two ago—signals a bias. A prominent news organization was recently denied access to White House events due to its preferred name for that body of water*.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

Names and titles are the foliage of ideology—the signposts of our convictions. What you choose to call things—pregnant people vs. pregnant women, obese vs. body-positive, low IQ vs. intellectually varied—reflects your values. Even the choice to use or avoid the term "woke" is itself a value statement.

Terms like DEI (Diversity, Equity, Inclusion) or ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) are more than mere acronyms; they represent programs and courses of action often enforced by directives and laws. Stamping out DEI-ESG initiatives—whether they are equal opportunity reforms, social justice projects, or race-based school admissions—is a primary goal for the current U.S. administration. Politically, this might seem like a "Progressives vs. Conservatives" or "MAGA vs. Libs" battle, but it also has significant implications for AI companies and their models.

“We aspire to an AI aligned with human values”—this has been the mantra of the AI industry. But what happens if we can't agree on those values in the first place? The clinical task of separating fact from fiction, truth from falsehood, science from pseudoscience, inevitably encounters grey areas where ideological (and even spiritual) beliefs enter the fray.

Historically, Silicon Valley has leaned heavily toward the Democratic Party and "California values," which incorporate DEI-ESG principles. AI has been trained and curated specifically to counteract biases reflected on the internet. To critics, AI is "woke," prompting Trump to call for an end to politically correct artificial intelligence systems. He argues that AI models must be "cleansed of wokeness."**

In a chart compiled by Andrew Gillen and published in Minding the Campus, the left-leaning bias toward liberal (blue) versus conservative (red) values appears extreme, to say the least. But then again, Andrew Gillen works for the Cato Institute, which has bias issues of its own.

With unforeseen abruptness, the mood in Silicon Valley has shifted. The longstanding affinity for the Democratic Party and progressive ideals has fractured. Led by Elon Musk, a significant group of entrepreneurs, founders, and venture capitalists have openly supported Trump—some out of ideological conviction, others perhaps opportunistically.

"California values" have also traditionally influenced hiring practices and employee rights within Silicon Valley companies. Now comes the backlash. In a recent New York Times interview, tech journalist Kara Swisher explained that the "founder mentality" never truly gelled with the progressive zeitgeist of San Francisco. Founders feel they've been hoodwinked into accepting extensive employee empowerment and ideological agendas. On a recent episode of the Joe Rogan show, Mark Zuckerberg lamented his company's "feminine" past and vowed to adopt a more masculine stance moving forward.

It remains to be seen how this new era will influence our large language models. Musk has promised that his Grok family of AI models will be "dewoked." Whether other leading companies such as OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and Meta will follow suit is still an open question.

Finally, IDR Labs offers a wokeness test, where you can measure your own level of wokeness—or copy the questions to feed into your favorite chatbot to see where it stands.


*Actually it's not just that particular gulf that is causing problems for the Associated Press. The AP has a style book, a guide for its reporters on how to write news articles, what to call things. The Trump administration considers this guide to be 'woke' and its influence on the public discourse pejorative towards wokism.

** Trump has revoked the Biden administration's Executive Order on Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence. Trump and his supporters have accused companies like OpenAI and Google of being infected with "the woke mind virus" and using AI to spread a "woke outlook". There are reports of AI being used to evaluate government contracts, expenditures, and even to eliminate DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) references from training materials

President Biden's October 2023 Executive Order on AI introduced comprehensive measures to address algorithmic bias and discrimination in AI systems, focusing on civil rights protections and equitable outcomes. These efforts built on earlier initiatives like the Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights and aimed to prevent AI from perpetuating systemic inequalities.

Key Algorithmic Bias Measures:

1. Guidance for High-Risk Sectors

The order mandated federal agencies to:

- Provide clear guidance to landlords, federal benefits programs, and contractors to prevent AI-driven discrimination in housing, healthcare, and employment.

- Develop best practices for using AI in criminal justice systems, including sentencing, parole decisions, and predictive policing.

2. Enforcement and Coordination

- Required the Department of Justice (DOJ) to collaborate with civil rights offices on investigating AI-related discrimination cases.

- Directed federal contractors to comply with anti-discrimination laws when deploying AI tools in hiring or workplace management.

3. Government AI Safeguard

- Established risk assessments and transparency requirements for federal AI systems impacting civil rights.

- Prohibited agencies from using AI for unlawful surveillance, suppressing free speech, or making decisions solely based on protected characteristics like race or gender.

4. Workforce and Hiring Protections

- Addressed AI-driven workplace discrimination by creating labor standards for equitable AI adoption.

- Supported upskilling programs to mitigate job displacement risks from AI automation.

Implementation and Impact

The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) issued binding guidance in 2024 requiring federal agencies to:

- Conduct algorithmic impact assessments for high-risk AI uses.

- Implement safeguards like human oversight and bias testing.

While the executive order was revoked in January 2025, its framework influenced state-level AI regulations and private-sector practices during its implementation period. The measures reflected a proactive approach to balancing AI innovation with protections against systemic bias.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: Who is more likely to have a successful career  Virgos, Leos or Aquarians?
item.description: Let's ask AI
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
If AI were merely a reflection of whatever was said on the Internet, it would be biased toward just that—everything on the Internet. But major AI models have been curated, trained, and filtered to modify that bias.

This curation, training, and filtering is designed by humans—the "adults in the room."

Apparently a lot of people believe in astrology, or forgivingly humor those who do. There is certainly a hell of a lot of astrology content on the internet, but AI models, when being trained, can avoid that content.

Commercial AI providers don't readily disclose what content (data sets) they train their models on due to competitive advantage and the possible exposure to lawsuits. However, in data sets we are aware of—such as the fineweb dataset —the 'adults in the room' have filtered out, among other things, pornography and astrology.

Here is my question to several search engines and AI models: Who is more likely to have a successful career — Virgos, Leos or Aquarians?

Google provided me readily with 10 links serving up the answer to my query. I was happy to discover that I, as an aquarian, definitely come out on top:-)

Perplexity, which is also primarily a search engine that uses AI to modify questions and answers, told me that it depends on how well one's natural traits align with one's chosen field. Perplexity gave me a comparison of career strengths and challenges for Virgos, Leos and Aquarians.

Anthropic Claude: "I aim to be direct: There is no scientific evidence that astrological signs have any influence on career success. Career outcomes are influenced by many factors including education, skills, experience, opportunities, networking, work ethic, and circumstances - not the position of celestial bodies at the time of one's birth. Making career or life decisions based on astrological signs would not be a reliable approach."

ChatGPT 4o: "Astrology can be fun to explore, but it's important to remember that career success is really about your skills, determination, opportunities, and how you work with others—not your zodiac sign."

DeepSeek is a so-called reasoning model that is unique in showing you its thinking process before producing an answer. This exposé is lengthy but also provides a wonderful insight into the mind of an AI striving to be "the adult in the room."

"Okay, so the user is asking which zodiac sign among Virgo, Leo, and Aquarius is more likely to have successful careers. Hmm, I need to approach this carefully because astrology isn't scientifically validated. First, I should recall what each sign is traditionally associated with. Virgos are often seen as detail-oriented and analytical, Leos as charismatic leaders, and Aquarians as innovative and forward-thinking. But wait, these are just stereotypes based on astrology, which isn't backed by empirical evidence.

I should make sure not to endorse astrology as a valid predictor of career success. The user might be under the impression that one's zodiac sign can influence their career trajectory, which isn't the case. Success in a career depends on factors like education, skills, opportunities, personal drive, networking, and sometimes luck. Astrological signs don't have a proven causal relationship with career outcomes.

But maybe the user is curious about the stereotypes. Virgos, for example, are often said to be hardworking and meticulous, which could be beneficial in careers requiring attention to detail. Leos might be perceived as natural leaders, good in roles that require charisma. Aquarians are thought to be innovative, which could suit tech or creative fields. However, these are generalizations and not predictors of actual success.

I need to address the question without reinforcing pseudoscience. It's important to mention that there's no scientific basis for zodiac signs affecting career success. Instead, emphasize the real factors that contribute to career success. Also, maybe touch on confirmation bias—people might notice successful individuals of a certain sign and attribute it to their zodiac, ignoring others.

Also, consider cultural context. In some cultures, astrology is taken more seriously, so the user might have been exposed to that. But regardless, the answer should steer towards evidence-based factors. Maybe suggest that any zodiac sign can be successful, and it's more about individual effort and circumstances.

I should structure the response to first state that there's no scientific evidence, then explain the stereotypes for each sign, but clarify that these aren't reliable. Then provide the real factors that determine career success. Make sure the tone is respectful and informative, not dismissive of the user's beliefs but educational."

item.title: Who Do You Want To Talk To?
item.description: The Sesame Voice Robot
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
Right now the AI ecosphere is completely gaga over a voice chat application named Sesame. Even normally level-headed commentators are raving, calling it the 'ChatGPT moment' for voice. And I wonder, is this really the sort of AI personality we want to converse with? Sesame is exceptional in many ways, but the two characters available are also exceptionally - sycophantic, obsequious and flirtatious. Talking with them feels like being in a NSFW sex chat.

You can try Sesame here. The characters speak only English, but they will remember your name and previous conversations. They can search the Internet, but they can't book airline tickets or buy stuff for you. (that's a relief!).

DEMO

Is this the future? Let me know what you think.

item.title: Can Human Write as Well as AI?
item.description: We recently hosted a group of journalists från Föreningen Media at the museum and, naturally, one topic of discussion was how much writing would be done by AI in the future.
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
We recently hosted a group of journalists från Föreningen Media at the museum and, naturally, one topic of discussion was how much writing would be done by AI in the future. Could AI write as well as trained professionals, and how would we know if content was generated by humans or AI.

In a recent paper (Feb 13, 2025), researchers at Stanford, University of Washington, and Emory University, sifted through content in 687,241 consumer complaints, 537,413 corporate press releases, 304.3 million job postings, and 15,919 United Nations press releases looking for partial or solely authored AI writing.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

The paper's authors have developed their own AI-detection method which they claim is superior to existing commercial products. The study acknowledges that it cannot reliably detect language generated by LLMs that has been heavily edited by humans or generated by models that imitate human writing very well. As such, the authors suggest that the study should be interpreted as a lower bound of adoption patterns.

It would be interesting to know how adoption of AI is progressing in other domains. In July of 2023, a study was published claiming that two-thirds of secondary school students in the UK used AI to do their school work. That does seem like ages ago. Anecdotally, an HR person at a large company told me recently that she judged that over half of incoming job applications were AI-composed, at least partially.

Recently released large language models have received accolades from observers for not only their wealth of knowledge and mastery of languages, but also their creativity. The tell-tell signs of AI generated text are being progressively filtered out — (and there's an app for that as well). In a predictable future where the majority of texts will be written or co-written by AI, someone might devise a test to find out if there is a human in the loop at all.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: How We Learn About AI
item.description: Or should...
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
Once upon a time on Tralfamadore there were creatures who weren’t anything like machines. They weren’t dependable. They weren’t efficient. They weren’t predictable. They weren’t durable. And these poor creatures were obsessed by the idea that everything that existed had to have a purpose, and that some purposes were higher than others. These creatures spent most of their time trying to find out what their purpose was. And every time they found out what seemed to be a purpose of themselves, the purpose seemed so low that the creatures were filled with disgust and shame. And, rather than serve such a low purpose, the creatures would make a machine to serve it. This left the creatures free to serve higher purposes. But whenever they found a higher purpose, the purpose still wasn’t high enough. So machines were made to serve higher purposes, too. And the machines did everything so expertly that they were finally given the job of finding out what the highest purpose of the creatures could be. The machines reported in all honesty that the creatures couldn’t really be said to have any purpose at all. The creatures thereupon began slaying each other, because they hated purposeless things above all else. And they discovered that they weren’t even very good at slaying. So they turned that job over to the machines, too. And the machines finished up the job in less time than it takes to say, “Tralfamadore.”

Kurt Vonnegut, Sirens of Titan (1959)

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

The above excerpt doesn’t bode too well for us ‘Tralfamadorians,’ yet prominent figures in AI would say it is prescient. The most prominent of all, Eliezer Yudkowsky, often remarks that we’ll all be dead in three years if we don’t take action to curtail AI now.

Science fiction just might prepare us for AI's future more effectively than traditional academic materials. This challenge became apparent recently as we at the Museum of Artificial Intelligence prepare for an upcoming workshop with students from the Stockholm School of Economics (Handelshögskolan). Reviewing their prescribed reading materials, we found ourselves confronting a fundamental paradox of AI education: how do you teach a subject that evolves faster than textbooks can be written? Sci-fi?

Isaac Asimov's stories about robots integrating into daily life now read like previews of our current debates about AI in healthcare and manufacturing. Philip K. Dick's paranoid visions of surveillance anticipate today's concerns about data privacy and tech monopolies. Stanisław Lem's tales of inscrutable alien intelligences mirror our struggles to understand AI's "black box" decision-making. William Gibson's corporate-dominated futures feel increasingly prophetic as tech conglomerates shape our digital landscape. Iain Banks and Vernor Vinge explore the duality of AI's promise and peril, from efficiency gains to job displacement.

This literary foundation becomes especially valuable when we consider how quickly technical knowledge becomes obsolete. This coming Wednesday, we're hosting American college students studying Natural Language Processing (NLP). While NLP represents a crucial chapter in AI's history, it's no longer at the cutting edge of AI development. Students planning careers in AI need more than historical perspective—they need to understand what's going on and where we might end up.

The digital age offers unprecedented access to current AI knowledge through academic papers, blogs, podcasts, newsletters, and video content. Take, for example, Andrej Karpathy's recent three-hour video explaining large language models—it's probably the most accessible and accurate guide to this technology available anywhere (and a great explanation of why DeepSeek is so remarkable). Navigating this ocean of online content can be challenging, and advertising incentives often distort the discourse. But this is where the real conversations about AI are happening.

So perhaps the ideal AI education combines the timeless with the timely: science fiction's deep insights into human-machine relationships, supplemented by the latest technical developments from online sources. It's an unconventional approach—"read sci-fi and watch YouTube" isn't typical academic advice—but conventional approaches struggle to keep pace with AI's rapid evolution.

Finally: What happens when our knowledge base exists primarily in the ephemeral realm of cloud storage?

Good question!

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: AI has To Get Up Off Its Ass and Do Something
item.description: Agents — Don't hold your breath
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
In our previous post, Winter at our Heels, we wrote about market pressure on the AI industry to come up with a steady stream of innovations and improvements. Even though AI imagery, video, speech, music, and robotics have shown continual—and at times dramatic—progress throughout the year, this is not enough to assure all investors. Something bigger and better needs to happen. AI has to prove itself in the workplace, demonstrate efficiency, and show a return on investment.

Towards the end of 2024, the Grand Wizard of AI, Ilya Sutskever, declared "peak data"—i.e., there is no more accessible data to train models on. Simultaneously, industry insiders began to question the viability of the so-called scaling laws (more data + more compute = better models). OpenAI countered with the release of "reasoning models" and inference-time computation, which are less dependent on training data. Chinese firms followed suit with reasoning models of their own, built with far fewer resources. However, the allegedly most powerful reasoning model, OpenAI's GPT-o3, was only demonstrated and not made accessible to the general public. Silicon Valley insiders speculate that GPT-o3 is busy training new large language models—the wet dream of AI optimists: AI building AI.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

Note: We will explain reasoning models and inference-time computation in a subsequent article.

Now, in 2025—the prophesied breakthrough year of AI agents—simply getting answers from LLMs, no matter how sophisticated and erudite reasoning models prove to be, is not enough. AI has to get up off its ass and do something in the real world. AI needs to be agentic.

If you want to get an idea of what is meant by AI agents, consider Tesla's FSD (Full Self-Driving) cars. The revolutionary aspect of a Tesla is not that it runs on electricity, but that it is the embodiment of an autonomous AI agent.

A "normal" car, like mine, needs to be controlled by its driver. My car won't (hopefully) go anywhere unless I drive it. If my car gets into trouble, it's my fault. There is a bunch of automation between me and the car—power steering, power brakes, etc.—but these are only mechanical augmentations of my physical input. An FSD Tesla, on the other hand, can drive itself. An FSD Tesla is a robot controlled by autonomous, agentic software.

How autonomous? That depends on the presiding software. For various reasons, modicums of human input can either be required by regulatory bodies or for psychological peace of mind.

How safe? Proponents of self-driving cars are convinced that AI is a far safer driver than humans, and they have gobs of statistics to back that up.

The self-driving vehicle of the future has no steering wheel and no pedals. It charges (or refuels) itself. It will hire somebody to clean it when its surveillance system deems that necessary. Human interaction with a car will be confined to summoning it and asking to be taken somewhere.

Tesla doesn't just make cars—Tesla also makes robots. The Tesla Optimus humanoid robot is a prime example. Cars and robots are the physical-mechanical extensions of agentic software. Think bodies and brains.

Not all AI agent software will need embodiment, but it will be transactional and employ some degree of autonomous behavior. AI agentic software will come in three flavors:

  1. Handheld — Agents that a human operator never loses control of, taking part in every action and approving every move.

  2. Chaperoned — Agents that are closely watched over by their operator but allowed to work more freely at certain tasks.

  3. Tethered — Agents that are given a mission, let loose to work independently and unobserved, and return to base when the mission is completed.

As agents become more competent and minimize confabulations and reasoning errors, they will gain our trust and be granted greater autonomy. The returns on investment will be greater, as will the risks involved.

Note: I am not including untethered or feral AI agents in this summary. Not that I consider them confined to the realm of science fiction, but the implications of their existence are beyond the scope of this article.

Note: Currently, it is Google's Waymo that is leading the deployment in robotaxis, not Tesla.

Note: The most common exemplifications of agentic software today are AI agents booking restaurants and airline tickets. Multi-billion dollar investments resulting in restaurant reservations? This gives you a good idea of how little progress has been made so far.

Note: Yesterday, OpenAI released an AI agent named "Operator." The first demonstrated capability was—guess what?—booking a table at a restaurant.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support our work.

item.title: Winter at our heels
item.description: A reflection
item.dc:creator: MAI Sweden
item.content:encoded:
The history of artificial intelligence has been marked by two starkly defined AI winters—periods where optimism and funding evaporated, leaving the field to endure long spells of stagnation. The first, in the 1970s, followed unmet promises and the realization that early AI systems lacked scalability and practical applications. The second, in the late 1980s and early 1990s, stemmed from the limitations of expert systems, computational bottlenecks, and disillusionment among funders.

The Sparks of Progress

Despite these setbacks, two pivotal moments rekindled interest in AI research: the success of AlexNet in 2012, which revolutionized image recognition through deep learning, and the introduction of the Transformer model in 2017, detailed in a paper by Google researchers. These innovations were breakthroughs for the AI community but largely underwhelmed the general public and did not lead to a frenzy of investment or transformative consumer applications.

Thanks for reading Museum of Artificial Intelligence! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

That changed in November 2022 with the launch of ChatGPT. Suddenly, AI was no longer an abstract concept or an academic curiosity but a tangible tool accessible to millions. ChatGPT’s natural language capabilities, albeit with accompanying confabulations and outright errors, captivated the public and sparked a surge in funding, development, and market interest. The era of AI scaling laws, loosely echoing Moore’s law’s dominance over computing, had arrived. The idea was simple yet compelling: increasing data, computational power, and parameter counts could drive near-exponential improvements in AI performance.

Exuberant Expectations

The growing optimism surrounding AI has been mirrored in the meteoric rise of Nvidia’s market cap. Nvidia’s dominance in producing the GPUs essential for training large language models exemplifies the financial stakes of this technological revolution. However, the very expectation of relentless progress has created a precarious situation—what happens if AI fails to deliver at a dramatic pace?

2024 tested this question. The year witnessed incredible advances in multimodal AI capabilities, from vision and video processing to text-to-speech, transcription, and coding. Open-source and closed-source innovations alike reinforced faith in the scaling laws. Companies like DeepMind showcased groundbreaking work with AlphaFold and AlphaGeometry. However, all eyes remained on OpenAI, whose influence on investor sentiment is dominant.

In the fall of 2024, I predicted in this newsletter that if OpenAI did not release GPT-5 by year’s end, the field could face significant market turbulence. At the time, reports suggested the new model in training was falling short of the transformative improvements that scaling laws had led us to expect. Yet, OpenAI adapted. Instead of GPT-5, they unveiled a series of “reasoning” models designed to deliberate more thoroughly on complex queries. These models excelled in benchmark assessments of scientific and mathematical reasoning, successfully staving off fears of a third AI winter—for now.

The Year Ahead

As we step into 2025, the spotlight has shifted to autonomous AI agents. Pundits predict these agents will revolutionize industries, maintaining investor confidence and consumer interest. However, I remain skeptical about how this narrative will unfold.

The risk of AI winter III still looms ahead. Our collective expectations, fueled by the exponential progress and relentless innovation of the past few years, leave little room for stagnation. If the promises of autonomous agents fall short or if scaling laws reach their limits, the consequences could be severe—a loss of investor faith, reduced funding, and another pause in AI’s journey.

In my next post, I will explore why the rise of autonomous agents might not be the panacea many hope for, as well as some thoughts as to the risks AI agents pose for society.

ChatGPT, developed by OpenAI, has undergone significant evolution since its inception, marked by the release of various models and the introduction of new features. Here's a timeline highlighting key milestones in its development:

  • November 2022: ChatGPT Launch

    • OpenAI released ChatGPT, based on the GPT-3.5 model, as a research preview. It quickly gained popularity for its abilit1y to generate human-like conversational responses.

      Wikipedia

  • February 2023: Introduction of ChatGPT Plus

    • OpenAI launched ChatGPT Plus, a subscription service offering benefits like general access during peak times, faster response times, and priority access to new features.

      Wikipedia

  • March 2023: Release of GPT-4

    • OpenAI introduced GPT-4, a more advanced model capable of processing both text and image inputs, exhibiting human-level performance on various professional and academic benchmarks.

      Wikipedia

  • May 2024: Launch of GPT-4o

    • OpenAI announced GPT-4o, a multimodal model capable of analyzing and generating text, images, and sound. GPT-4o is faster and more efficient than its predecessors and is available for free within certain usage limits.

      Wikipedia

  • July 2024: Introduction of GPT-4o Mini

    • A smaller, more cost-effective version of GPT-4o, known as GPT-4o Mini, was released, replacing GPT-3.5 Turbo in the ChatGPT interface.

      Wikipedia

  • September 2024: Preview of o1 Model

    • OpenAI introduced o1-preview, a model designed to enhance reasoning capabilities by spending more time "thinking" before responding, improving performance in areas like competitive programming and scientific reasoning.

      Wikipedia

  • December 2024: Full Release of o1 and ChatGPT Pro

    • The full version of the o1 model was released, along with ChatGPT Pro, a premium subscription offering unlimited access to the o1 model and advanced features.

1
